docs.lead_paragraph: The early morning sun shone brightly on the tiny wooden coffin coated in white velvet. It sat next to a heap of earth, ready for burial, among the brass plaques marking graves adorned with rubber duckies, pacifiers and toy Santas. The newborn girl, Mary Hope, had been found dead in a bag by workers sorting through recyclables and trash trucked to a Brooklyn plant. So for the 11th time in a year and a half, Timothy Jaccard, a Nassau County paramedic, stood graveside on Saturday with a clutch of fellow paramedics, police officers and strangers, grasping for the right thing to say about a baby found in the garbage.

headline.main: Dignity for the Tiniest Victims; Paramedics Arrange Funerals for Abandoned Infants

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The column ''Yesterday's Precocious Puberty Is Norm Today'' links earlier sexual maturation of girls to better nutrition. But if present-day nutrition leads to such an unfortunate results as the capacity for preteen pregnancy, why call it ''better''? EION MC RAE Whitehouse Station, N.J.
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    The column ''Yesterday's Precocious Puberty Is Norm Today''  links earlier sexual maturation of girls to better nutrition. But if present-day nutrition leads to such an unfortunate results as the capacity for preteen pregnancy, why...

docs.lead_paragraph: Maggie Lee, a 60-year-old Harlem resident, spends her days as an aide to an 86-year-old woman who lives in Washington Heights. When she gets home, she looks after four grandchildren and her husband, who had his left leg amputated below the knee because of diabetes. This was not the sort of hectic schedule that Ms. Lee had envisioned for herself as she neared retirement age. But in November 1992 Ms. Lee learned that her daughter, Patricia, had been shot and killed after an argument. That the argument was over a broken freezer, and that the man who shot her daughter was the building superintendent, added to the meaninglessness of the death.

headline.main: At Threshold of Old Age, Still Caring for Children

docs.lead_paragraph: A new study of nearly 600,000 births offers surprising answers to a question that has always worried women who find themselves trapped in difficult labor: What is the safest way to deliver the baby? Although many doctors and patients have long assumed that a Caesarean section would be best for the baby, the new study suggests otherwise, indicating that if a woman is already in labor, delivery by forceps or a vacuum tool can be just as safe.

headline.main: Study Finds Surprising Data on Safe Births: Caesarean's Risks Are Similar to Other Methods

docs.abstract: New study of nearly 600,000 births suggests that for woman already in difficult labor, delivery by forceps or vacuum tool can be just as safe for baby as Caesarean section, currently preferred procedure; all three methods are associated with slightly greater risk of brain hemorrhage in infant than normal delivery (M)
